canonical_explanation.text: For Class 11, p-block elements covers Groups 13 (boron family) and 14 (carbon family). Group 13 elements (B, Al, Ga, In, Tl) have ns²np¹ configuration with +3 as the common oxidation state, though the inert pair effect makes +1 stable for heavier elements like Tl. Boron is a metalloid; aluminium is amphoteric. Important boron compounds include borax (Na₂B₄O₇·10H₂O), boric acid (H₃BO₃), and diborane (B₂H₆) with its unique three-centre two-electron bonds. Group 14 elements (C, Si, Ge, Sn, Pb) have ns²np² configuration; carbon shows catenation (forming long chains) and exists as allotropes (diamond, graphite, fullerenes). Silicon forms silicones (organosilicon polymers), silicates, and zeolites. The inert pair effect is prominent in Pb, which favors +2 state.
rules: Group 13: +3 oxidation state is common; inert pair effect makes +1 stable for Tl.
Boron is electron-deficient and forms three-centre two-electron (3c-2e) bonds in diborane.
Group 14: Carbon shows catenation (ability to form long C-C chains); silicon does not catenate well due to weaker Si-Si bonds.
Allotropes of carbon: diamond (sp³, hardest), graphite (sp², conductor), fullerene (C₆₀, soccer-ball shape).

questions.question_text: The general electronic configuration of Group 13 elements is:
questions.explanation_correct: The general electronic configuration of Group 13 elements is ns² np¹, as the group has 3 valence electrons and the configuration has 2 electrons in the s-orbital and 1 electron in the p-orbital.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) ns² np¹. Group 13 elements have 3 valence electrons, so their electronic configuration is not ns² np², ns¹ np², or ns² np³. The ns² np¹ configuration best represents the electron distribution in the valence shell of Group 13 elements.

questions.question_text: Boron is a:
questions.explanation_correct: Boron is a metalloid, which means it has properties intermediate between metals and nonmetals. It has a shiny appearance like a metal, but is a poor conductor of electricity and heat, which are nonmetal properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boron is not a metal, as it does not have high electrical and thermal conductivity, malleability, and ductility like metals. It is also not a nonmetal, as it is not a gaseous element at room temperature and has a shiny appearance. Boron is classified as a metalloid, an element with properties between metals and nonmetals.

questions.question_text: The most stable oxidation state of thallium (Tl) is +1 rather than +3 due to the:
questions.explanation_correct: The inert pair effect causes the heavier p-block elements like thallium (Tl) to prefer the +1 oxidation state over the +3 state, even though +3 is the expected valency from the ns²np¹ electronic configuration. This is due to the stability imparted by the lone pair of electrons in the outermost 6s orbital.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The large atomic radius, high electronegativity, or absence of d-orbitals do not directly cause the +1 oxidation state to be more stable for thallium. The key reason is the inert pair effect, where the 6s electrons in the outermost shell of Tl become reluctant to participate in bonding, making the +1 state more favorable than the expected +3 state.

questions.question_text: Aluminium hydroxide is amphoteric. It reacts with NaOH to form:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) NaAlO₂ + H₂O. Aluminium hydroxide (Al(OH)₃) is amphoteric, meaning it can react with both acids and bases. When it reacts with the base sodium hydroxide (NaOH), it forms sodium aluminate (NaAlO₂) and water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A) Al₂O₃ + H₂O is incorrect because aluminium hydroxide does not directly form aluminium oxide when reacted with NaOH. Option C) Al(OH)₃ + NaCl is incorrect because aluminium hydroxide reacts with NaOH to form a new compound, not just combine with NaCl. Option D) Na₃Al + H₂O is incorrect because aluminium hydroxide does not form metallic sodium when reacted with NaOH.

questions.question_text: The general electronic configuration of Group 14 elements is:
questions.explanation_correct: The general electronic configuration of Group 14 elements is ns²np², as these elements have 4 valence electrons which are arranged in the s and p orbitals, giving them a stable configuration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct electronic configuration of Group 14 elements is ns²np², not the other options. Option A (ns²np¹) is the configuration of Group 13 elements, Option C (ns²np³) is the configuration of Group 15 elements, and Option D (ns²np⁴) is the configuration of the noble gases.

questions.question_text: The ability of carbon to form long chains with itself is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The ability of carbon to form long chains with itself is called catenation. This is a unique property of carbon that allows it to form a wide variety of organic compounds by linking up with other carbon atoms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ability of carbon to form long chains with itself is not called allotropy, which refers to the existence of different physical forms of the same element. It is also not called isomerism, which refers to the existence of different structural arrangements of the same molecular formula. Polymerization is the formation of large molecules from smaller ones, but catenation specifically refers to the ability of carbon to form long chains.

questions.question_text: In diamond, each carbon atom is:

options.text: sp² hybridized and bonded to 3 other carbons
sp³ hybridized and bonded to 4 other carbons
sp hybridized and bonded to 2 other carbons
Unhybridized and bonded to 6 other carbons

questions.explanation_correct: In diamond, each carbon atom is sp³ hybridized, meaning it has four equivalent hybrid orbitals that are directed towards the four corners of a tetrahedron. This allows each carbon to form four single covalent bonds to four other carbon atoms, resulting in the characteristic tetrahedral structure of diamond.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because: A) Carbon in diamond is not sp² hybridized, which would result in a planar structure with only three bonds; C) Carbon in diamond is not sp hybridized, which would result in a linear structure with only two bonds; and D) Carbon in diamond is not unhybridized, as this would not explain the observed tetrahedral bonding arrangement.

questions.question_text: Graphite conducts electricity because:

options.text: Each carbon is sp² hybridized with delocalized electrons above and below the layers

questions.explanation_correct: Graphite conducts electricity because the carbon atoms in each layer are sp² hybridized, forming delocalized electrons above and below the layers. These free-flowing electrons allow graphite to conduct electricity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Graphite does not conduct electricity because of ionic bonds or metallic bonds. It also does not contain free metal ions. The correct reason is that the carbon atoms in graphite are sp² hybridized, which creates a network of delocalized electrons that can move freely and conduct electricity.

questions.question_text: The chemical formula of borax is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct formula for borax is Na₂B₄O₇·10H₂O because borax is a hydrated sodium borate, with a formula that includes four boron atoms, seven oxygen atoms, and ten water molecules.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct formula for borax. Option B is the formula for boric acid (H₃BO₃), option C is the formula for sodium metaborate (NaBO₂), and option D is the formula for diborane (B₂H₆), which is a boron hydride compound. Borax has a more complex formula that includes sodium, boron, oxygen, and water of crystallization.

questions.question_text: Boric acid (H₃BO₃) is a:

options.text: Monobasic Lewis acid that accepts OH⁻ from water

questions.explanation_correct: Boric acid (H₃BO₃) is a monobasic Lewis acid because it can accept an OH⁻ ion from water, forming the conjugate base B(OH)₄⁻. This makes it a weak acid that donates only 1 proton, not 3 like a triprotic acid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boric acid is not a triprotic acid, as it only has one acidic hydrogen that can be donated. It is also not a strong acid, as it is a weak acid that partially dissociates in water. Boric acid is a Lewis acid, meaning it accepts an OH⁻ ion from water to form the conjugate base B(OH)₄⁻, making it a monobasic acid.

questions.question_text: Diborane (B₂H₆) has a unique structure containing:
questions.explanation_correct: Diborane (B₂H₆) has a unique structure with four 2-centre 2-electron (2c-2e) bonds and two 3-centre 2-electron (banana) bonds, which is the correct answer. This unusual bonding arrangement helps stabilize the molecule.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect. Diborane does not have six normal 2c-2e bonds, nor does it have three double bonds or six 3c-2e bonds. The unique structure with four 2c-2e bonds and two 3c-2e bonds is what makes diborane special and stable.

questions.question_text: BF₃ acts as a Lewis acid because:

options.text: It has an incomplete octet and can accept a lone pair of electrons
It has lone pairs to donate

questions.explanation_correct: BF₃ acts as a Lewis acid because it has an incomplete octet and can accept a lone pair of electrons from another molecule, forming a coordinate covalent bond.
questions.explanation_incorrect: BF₃ does not act as a Lewis acid by donating a proton (option A) or having lone pairs to donate (option C). It is also not ionic (option D). BF₃ is a neutral, covalent compound that can accept a lone pair of electrons, making it a Lewis acid.

questions.question_text: Fullerene (C₆₀) has the shape of a:
questions.explanation_correct: Fullerene C₆₀ has a unique structure that resembles a truncated icosahedron, which is the shape of a soccer ball. This 3D structure is formed by the arrangement of 60 carbon atoms in a highly symmetrical pattern.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fullerene C₆₀ does not have a cubic, tetrahedral, or flat sheet structure. These shapes are not characteristic of the fullerene molecule, which is a spherical, cage-like structure composed of 60 carbon atoms arranged in a truncated icosahedron pattern.

questions.question_text: Silicones are polymers containing:

options.text: Si-O-Si linkages with organic groups attached to Si

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B because silicones are polymers that contain Si-O-Si linkages with organic groups (such as methyl or phenyl groups) attached to the silicon atoms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because: A) Silicones contain Si-O-Si linkages, not just Si-C bonds. C) Silicones are not just C-C chains, they have the characteristic Si-O-Si backbone. D) Silicones do not contain B-O bonds, they are composed of silicon, oxygen, and organic groups.

questions.question_text: Zeolites are:

options.text: Hydrated aluminosilicates with a framework structure containing channels

questions.explanation_correct: Zeolites are hydrated aluminosilicates with a framework structure containing channels, which makes them useful as molecular sieves and catalysts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zeolites are not pure forms of silicon dioxide (option B), nor are they allotropes of carbon (option C) or boron hydrides (option D). Zeolites have a specific framework structure with channels that allow them to be used as molecular sieves and catalysts.

questions.question_text: The most common oxidation state of aluminium is:
questions.explanation_correct: The most common oxidation state of aluminium is +3. This is because aluminium has an electronic configuration of [Ne] 3s² 3p¹, which allows it to form three covalent bonds and achieve a stable octet configuration by losing three electrons to form the +3 oxidation state.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because the +1 and +2 oxidation states are not the most common for aluminium. The +4 oxidation state is also not common for aluminium, as it would require the element to exceed its octet configuration. Aluminium predominantly forms compounds in the +3 oxidation state, as this allows it to achieve a stable electron configuration.

questions.question_text: CO is a poisonous gas because it:

options.text: Forms a stable complex with hemoglobin (carboxyhemoglobin), blocking O₂ transport
Decomposes to C and O in the blood

questions.explanation_correct: CO is poisonous because it forms a stable complex with hemoglobin in the blood, called carboxyhemoglobin. This blocks the transport of oxygen in the body, leading to asphyxiation and suffocation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CO does not react with stomach acid, decompose to C and O in the blood, or dissolve in blood plasma. The correct reason is that CO binds strongly to hemoglobin, preventing it from carrying oxygen throughout the body, which can be fatal if exposure continues.

questions.question_text: The anomalous behavior of boron compared to other Group 13 elements is due to its:

options.text: Small size, high ionization enthalpy, and absence of d-orbitals

questions.explanation_correct: The anomalous behavior of boron is due to its small size, high ionization enthalpy, and absence of d-orbitals, which make it different from the other larger and more metallic Group 13 elements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boron is a metalloid, not a metal, so choice A is incorrect. Boron's small size and high ionization enthalpy, not its large atomic radius (choice C) or low electronegativity (choice D), are the reasons for its unique properties compared to the other Group 13 elements.

questions.question_text: Silicon does not show catenation as well as carbon because:

options.text: Si-Si bond is stronger than C-C bond
Si-Si bond enthalpy is much lower than C-C bond enthalpy

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Si-Si bond enthalpy is much lower than C-C bond enthalpy. This means that it requires less energy to break the silicon-silicon bonds compared to the stronger carbon-carbon bonds. Therefore, silicon does not show catenation as readily as carbon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Si-Si bond enthalpy is much lower than C-C bond enthalpy. The weaker silicon-silicon bonds make it harder for silicon to form long chains and catenate, unlike the stronger carbon-carbon bonds that allow carbon to form a wide variety of compounds with long, branched structures. Options A, C, and D are incorrect because the Si-Si bond strength, electronegativity, and availability of p-orbitals are not the primary reasons for the lack of catenation in silicon.

questions.question_text: When borax is dissolved in water, it forms:
questions.explanation_correct: When borax (Na₂B₄O₇·10H₂O) is dissolved in water, it forms a basic (alkaline) solution. This is because borax is a salt of a weak acid (boric acid, H₃BO₃) and a strong base (sodium hydroxide, NaOH), which results in a basic solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because: (A) Borax is not an acidic compound, so it would not form an acidic solution. (C) Borax is a basic compound, so it would not form a neutral solution. (D) Borax does not form a buffer solution, which is a mixture of a weak acid and its conjugate base or a weak base and its conjugate acid.

questions.question_text: AlCl₃ exists as a dimer (Al₂Cl₆) in the vapour phase because:

options.text: Aluminium has vacant p-orbitals that accept lone pairs from Cl
Chlorine cannot form bonds with aluminium
The Al-Cl bond is purely ionic

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A because aluminium has vacant p-orbitals that can accept the lone pairs from chlorine atoms, forming a dimer structure (Al₂Cl₆) in the vapour phase to achieve a more stable configuration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct explanation is that aluminium has vacant p-orbitals that can accept the lone pairs from chlorine atoms, forming a dimer structure (Al₂Cl₆) in the vapour phase. Options B, C, and D are incorrect because the large size of aluminium, the inability of chlorine to form bonds with aluminium, and the ionic nature of the Al-Cl bond, respectively, are not the reasons for the dimer formation.

questions.question_text: The most stable allotrope of carbon under standard conditions is:
questions.explanation_correct: Graphite is the most stable allotrope of carbon under standard conditions. This is because the carbon atoms in graphite are arranged in a hexagonal, planar structure that allows for extensive delocalization of the electrons, making it the most thermodynamically stable form of carbon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diamond is a metastable allotrope of carbon, meaning it is less stable than graphite under standard conditions. While diamond has a higher energy barrier to transformation, graphite is the preferred form of carbon due to its more stable hexagonal structure and delocalized electron system. Fullerenes and carbon nanotubes are other allotropes of carbon, but they are not the most stable under standard conditions.

questions.question_text: Silicates are built from the basic structural unit:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) SiO₄⁴⁻ tetrahedron. Silicates are built up from this basic structural unit, where each silicon atom is surrounded by four oxygen atoms in a tetrahedral arrangement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct basic structural unit of silicates. Option A) SiO₂ is the formula for silicon dioxide, but not the fundamental unit. Option C) Si₂O₃ and Option D) SiO₃²⁻ linear unit are also not the correct basic building blocks of silicates. The SiO₄⁴⁻ tetrahedron is the key structural unit that forms the backbone of silicate minerals and compounds.

questions.question_text: Down Group 13, the tendency to form M³⁺ ions _____ due to the inert pair effect.
questions.explanation_correct: The tendency to form M³⁺ ions decreases down Group 13 due to the inert pair effect. As the atoms get heavier, the 6s electrons become more stable and less reactive, making the +1 oxidation state more stable compared to the +3 state.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Decreases. This is because as you go down Group 13, the inert pair effect becomes more pronounced. The 6s electrons become more stable and are less likely to participate in bonding, making the +1 oxidation state more favorable compared to the +3 state.

questions.question_text: CO₂ is a linear molecule while SiO₂ is a 3D network solid because:

options.text: Carbon is more electronegative than silicon
Carbon forms pπ-pπ multiple bonds with O, while Si forms only single bonds due to its larger size

questions.explanation_correct: Carbon is able to form pπ-pπ multiple bonds with oxygen due to its small size and high electronegativity, resulting in a linear CO2 molecule. Silicon, being larger in size, can only form single bonds with oxygen, leading to a 3D network solid structure in SiO2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because while carbon is more electronegative than silicon, this does not explain the difference in molecular structures of CO2 and SiO2. Option C is incorrect because SiO2 contains covalent bonds, not ionic bonds. Option D is incorrect because the molecular mass of CO2 and SiO2 does not determine their structures.

questions.question_text: Boric acid has a layered structure held together by:
questions.explanation_correct: Boric acid has a layered structure held together by hydrogen bonds between the hydroxyl (-OH) groups of adjacent boric acid molecules. The hydrogen bonds form a network that stabilizes the layered structure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boric acid does not have ionic, metallic, or covalent network bonds holding its structure together. The hydrogen bonds between the hydroxyl groups of adjacent boric acid molecules are responsible for the layered structure of this compound.

questions.question_text: The first ionization enthalpy of B is higher than that of Al because:

options.text: B has a larger atomic radius
B has a smaller atomic radius and no inner d-electrons for shielding

questions.explanation_correct: The first ionization enthalpy of boron (B) is higher than that of aluminium (Al) because B has a smaller atomic radius and does not have any inner d-electrons to shield the nuclear charge, making it harder to remove an electron from B compared to Al.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because a larger atomic radius would actually decrease the first ionization enthalpy, not increase it. Option C is incorrect because having more protons in the nucleus of Al would make it harder to remove an electron, not easier. Option D is incorrect because having more electrons does not directly affect the first ionization enthalpy - the key factor is the atomic radius and shielding effects.

questions.question_text: The oxidation state of lead (Pb) that is most stable is:
questions.explanation_correct: The most stable oxidation state of lead (Pb) is +2. This is due to the inert pair effect, where the 6s electrons in lead tend to remain un-ionized, making the +2 state more stable compared to the higher +4 state.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The +4 oxidation state is less stable for lead compared to the +2 state. This is because lead prefers to keep its 6s electrons 'inert' or un-ionized, making the +2 state more stable. The 0 and -2 oxidation states are very uncommon for lead and thus incorrect.

questions.question_text: Silicones are used as lubricants and sealants because they:

options.text: Are chemically inert, water-repellent, and thermally stable

questions.explanation_correct: Silicones are chemically inert, water-repellent, and thermally stable, which makes them useful as lubricants and sealants. Their unique properties come from the silicon-oxygen backbone and organic side chains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silicones are not water-soluble because they have a silicon-oxygen backbone with organic side chains, which makes them hydrophobic. They are also not strong acids, as they are neutral compounds. Additionally, silicones are not good electrical conductors, as they are made of non-metallic elements.

questions.question_text: The halide of a Group 13 element that is ionic is:
questions.explanation_correct: The halide of a Group 13 element that is ionic is AlF₃. The Group 13 elements have a common +3 oxidation state, and the fluoride ion (F-) is highly electronegative, so it forms an ionic bond with the Al³+ cation to create the ionic compound AlF₃.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not ionic halides of Group 13 elements. BF₃ and BBr₃ are covalent compounds, while AlCl₃ is also an ionic compound. The key difference is that fluoride (F-) forms stronger ionic bonds compared to other halogens like chlorine (Cl-) or bromine (Br-), making AlF₃ the most ionic halide of a Group 13 element.

questions.question_text: Which carbon allotrope is the hardest known natural substance?
questions.explanation_correct: Diamond is the hardest known natural substance because of its unique crystal structure. The carbon atoms in diamond are arranged in a tightly-bonded cubic lattice, making it an extremely hard and durable material.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Graphite is a type of carbon that forms soft, flaky layers, so it is not the hardest natural substance. Fullerenes are a family of carbon allotropes that have a spherical or cylindrical shape, and charcoal is a porous carbon material, neither of which are as hard as diamond.

questions.question_text: The borax bead test is used to identify:

options.text: Coloured metal ions by forming metal metaborates
Acidic or basic nature of solutions

questions.explanation_correct: The borax bead test is used to identify the presence of coloured metal ions in a sample. When a sample containing metal ions is heated in a borax bead, the borax forms a glassy bead that can take on different colours depending on the metal present, allowing its identification.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The borax bead test does not identify anions in salts, determine the acidic or basic nature of solutions, or detect the carbon content in organic compounds. It is specifically used to identify the presence of coloured metal ions by forming characteristic coloured metal metaborates when the sample is heated in the borax bead.

questions.question_text: CCl₄ is not hydrolyzed by water while SiCl₄ is readily hydrolyzed because:

options.text: Si has vacant d-orbitals to accept lone pairs from water; C does not
C-Cl bond is weaker than Si-Cl bond
CCl₄ has a higher molecular mass

questions.explanation_correct: Silicon (Si) has vacant d-orbitals that can accept lone pairs from water molecules, making SiCl₄ readily hydrolyzed. In contrast, carbon (C) does not have any vacant d-orbitals, so CCl₄ is not easily hydrolyzed by water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is incorrect because the C-Cl bond is not necessarily weaker than the Si-Cl bond. Option C is incorrect because the ionic nature of a compound does not determine its hydrolysis. Option D is incorrect because the molecular mass of the compound does not affect its hydrolysis behavior. The correct answer is A, as the presence of vacant d-orbitals in silicon allows it to accept lone pairs from water, facilitating hydrolysis of SiCl₄.

questions.question_text: Thermite reaction (2Al + Fe₂O₃ → Al₂O₃ + 2Fe) works because aluminium is a:
questions.explanation_correct: Aluminium is a strong reducing agent, which means it can easily give up its electrons to other elements. In the thermite reaction, aluminium reduces iron(III) oxide (Fe₂O₃) to pure iron, while itself getting oxidized to aluminium oxide (Al₂O₃). This reaction releases a large amount of heat, making it useful for welding and controlled explosions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The thermite reaction is not caused by aluminium being a strong oxidizing agent, which would mean it can easily accept electrons. Aluminium is actually a reducing agent that donates its electrons to iron(III) oxide, reducing it to pure iron metal. It is also not acting as a catalyst, as it is directly involved in the chemical reaction. Finally, aluminium is not considered a weak metal - it is a highly reactive metal that can easily form compounds.

questions.question_text: Zeolites are used as:
questions.explanation_correct: Zeolites are used as shape-selective catalysts in the petrochemical industry because their porous structure allows molecules of certain sizes and shapes to enter and undergo chemical reactions, while excluding larger molecules.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zeolites are not used as fuels, food additives, or reducing agents. They are a type of aluminosilicate mineral with a microporous structure that makes them useful as catalysts in chemical processes, particularly in the petrochemical industry where they can selectively allow certain molecules to react while excluding others.

questions.question_text: All Group 13 elements are metals.
questions.explanation_correct: Not all Group 13 elements are metals. Boron, the first element in Group 13, is a metalloid, meaning it has properties in between a metal and a non-metal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect because boron, the first element in Group 13, is not a metal. Boron is a metalloid, which means it has properties that are in between a metal and a non-metal. The other Group 13 elements (aluminum, gallium, indium, and thallium) are indeed metals, but the presence of a metalloid in the group means the statement 'all Group 13 elements are metals' is false.

questions.question_text: Diamond is a good conductor of electricity because all four valence electrons of carbon are involved in bonding.
questions.explanation_correct: Diamond is not a good conductor of electricity because the four valence electrons of carbon atoms in diamond are used to form strong covalent bonds. These bonds do not allow the free movement of electrons, which is necessary for electrical conductivity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false because the four valence electrons of carbon in diamond are involved in forming strong covalent bonds, which hold the carbon atoms together in a rigid, crystalline structure. This arrangement does not allow the free movement of electrons, which is required for a material to be a good conductor of electricity. Instead, diamond is an excellent electrical insulator.

questions.question_text: Borax dissolved in water produces a basic solution because it hydrolyzes to release OH⁻ ions.
questions.explanation_correct: Borax (sodium tetraborate, Na₂B₄O₇·10H₂O) is a salt of boric acid (H₃BO₃). When dissolved in water, it hydrolyzes to form boric acid and sodium hydroxide, making the solution basic (pH > 7) due to the presence of hydroxide (OH⁻) ions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect explanation would be that borax does not produce a basic solution when dissolved in water. This is because borax is a salt that undergoes hydrolysis, splitting into boric acid (H₃BO₃) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH). The presence of the hydroxide ions (OH⁻) is what makes the solution basic, with a pH greater than 7.

questions.question_text: PbO₂ is a stronger oxidizing agent than SnO₂ because Pb⁴⁺ readily gains electrons to achieve the more stable Pb²⁺ state.
questions.explanation_correct: PbO₂ is a stronger oxidizing agent than SnO₂ because the Pb⁴⁺ ion in PbO₂ can readily gain electrons to form the more stable Pb²⁺ ion, which is the common oxidation state for lead. This tendency to achieve the +2 state makes PbO₂ a stronger oxidant compared to SnO₂, where Sn⁴⁺ is less inclined to be reduced.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect because Sn⁴⁺ is actually the more stable oxidation state for tin, not Sn²⁺. PbO₂ is a stronger oxidizing agent than SnO₂ because Pb⁴⁺ can more easily gain electrons to reach the +2 oxidation state, which is the more common and stable form for lead. The inert pair effect makes the +2 state more favourable for heavier p-block elements like lead.

questions.question_text: The first ionization enthalpy of Ga is lower than that of Al due to poor shielding by the 3d electrons in Ga.
questions.explanation_correct: The first ionization enthalpy of Ga is lower than that of Al due to the increased shielding of the nuclear charge by the 3d electrons in Ga. This makes it easier to remove the 4s electron in Ga compared to the 3s electron in Al, resulting in a lower first ionization enthalpy for Ga.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The first ionization enthalpy of an element depends on the nuclear charge and the shielding of the nuclear charge by the inner electrons. Since Ga has a higher atomic number than Al, it has a greater nuclear charge. While Ga has 3d electrons that can provide some shielding, this shielding effect is not strong enough to overcome the higher nuclear charge in Ga compared to Al. Therefore, the first ionization enthalpy of Ga is actually higher than that of Al.

questions.question_text: The common oxidation state of Group 13 elements is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The common oxidation state of Group 13 elements is +3 because these elements have a ns²np¹ electron configuration. This means they have 3 valence electrons that can be easily lost to form a positive +3 oxidation state.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is '+3'. However, the incorrect answer could be something like '+1' or '+2'. This is because the heavier Group 13 elements like thallium (Tl) can also exhibit a +1 oxidation state due to the inert pair effect, where the 6s² electrons do not participate in bonding. But the most common oxidation state across the group is still +3.

questions.question_text: The allotrope of carbon in which each atom is sp² hybridized and arranged in hexagonal layers is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The allotrope of carbon that is described is graphite. In graphite, the carbon atoms are sp² hybridized and arranged in hexagonal layers, which gives graphite its characteristic layered structure and properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'graphite'. The other allotropes of carbon, such as diamond and fullerenes, do not have the same sp² hybridization and hexagonal layered structure as graphite. Therefore, graphite is the correct answer that fits the description provided in the question.

questions.question_text: Diborane (B₂H₆) contains ___ three-centre two-electron bonds.
questions.explanation_correct: Diborane (B₂H₆) contains 2 three-centre two-electron bonds. This unique type of bonding is required to accommodate the 6 hydrogen atoms around the 2 boron atoms, as boron has only 3 valence electrons. The three-centre bonds allow for the efficient sharing of electrons between the 2 boron and 6 hydrogen atoms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to say that diborane (B₂H₆) contains 1 three-centre two-electron bond. This is wrong because diborane has 2 such bonds, not 1. The correct answer is 2 three-centre two-electron bonds, as each boron atom forms one of these bonds with 2 hydrogen atoms.

questions.question_text: The C-C bond enthalpy is approximately ___ kJ/mol, while Si-Si is about 226 kJ/mol, explaining why carbon shows greater catenation.
questions.explanation_correct: The C-C bond enthalpy is approximately 348 kJ/mol, while the Si-Si bond enthalpy is about 226 kJ/mol. This higher bond enthalpy for C-C bonds compared to Si-Si bonds explains why carbon has a greater ability to form long chains and show catenation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is a number, in this case 348 kJ/mol. The question is asking for the approximate C-C bond enthalpy, which is higher than the Si-Si bond enthalpy of 226 kJ/mol. This difference in bond enthalpies allows carbon to form stronger and longer chains through catenation, compared to silicon.

questions.question_text: The basic structural unit of silicates is the ___ ion.
questions.explanation_correct: The basic structural unit of silicates is the SiO₄⁴⁻ ion. This is because silicon (Si) in the group 14 p-block element has a +4 oxidation state and forms four covalent bonds with oxygen (O) atoms, creating a tetrahedron-shaped SiO₄ unit. This SiO₄⁴⁻ ion is the fundamental building block of silicate minerals and compounds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be something like 'Si⁴⁺ ion'. While silicon does have a +4 oxidation state, the basic structural unit of silicates is actually the SiO₄⁴⁻ ion, where the silicon atom is bonded to four oxygen atoms in a tetrahedral arrangement. The SiO₄⁴⁻ ion, not just the Si⁴⁺ ion, is the fundamental unit that makes up silicate materials.

questions.question_text: The tendency of heavier Group 13 and 14 elements to show a lower oxidation state by 2 is called the ___ effect.
questions.explanation_correct: The tendency of heavier Group 13 and 14 elements to show a lower oxidation state by 2 is called the inert pair effect. This is because the s-electrons in the outermost shell of these elements become more tightly bound and difficult to remove, making the higher +4 or +5 oxidation states less stable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The inert pair effect refers to the tendency of heavier Group 13 and 14 elements to show a lower oxidation state by 2. For example, lead (Pb) in Group 14 prefers the +2 oxidation state over the +4 state, due to the inert pair effect. The accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is 'inert pair'.

questions.question_text: Silicones are organosilicon polymers with the repeating unit (R₂SiO)ₙ, where R is typically a ___ group.
questions.explanation_correct: Silicones are organosilicon polymers, meaning they contain both silicon and organic (carbon-based) groups. The repeating unit (R₂SiO)ₙ has R typically as a methyl (CH₃) group, which is an organic alkyl group that provides the necessary carbon-based functionality for silicones.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'methyl', which refers to the organic R group in the repeating unit of silicones. This is because silicones contain both silicon and organic carbon-based components, with the methyl group (CH₃) being a commonly used organic group in these polymers. Other options like 'hydrogen' or 'phenyl' would not correctly complete the structure of the silicone repeating unit.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following Group 13 elements in increasing order of first ionization enthalpy: (A) B, (B) Al, (C) Ga, (D) Tl
questions.explanation_correct: The first ionization enthalpy increases from Tl to B in the group because the effective nuclear charge increases as the atomic number increases, making it harder to remove the outermost electron from the atom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order of increasing first ionization enthalpy is Tl, Al, Ga, B. This is because the outermost electrons become more tightly held as you go up the group due to the increasing effective nuclear charge, making it harder to remove these electrons from the atom.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following carbon allotropes in increasing order of hardness: (A) Graphite, (B) Fullerene, (C) Diamond
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of increasing hardness of the carbon allotropes is Graphite, Fullerene, Diamond. Graphite is the softest carbon allotrope as it has weak interlayer van der Waals forces, while diamond is the hardest with a rigid tetrahedral structure of strong covalent bonds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Fullerene, Graphite, Diamond. Fullerene is not the hardest - it is actually softer than diamond. Diamond has the strongest covalent bonds and rigid tetrahedral structure, making it the hardest carbon allotrope. Graphite is the softest due to its weak interlayer forces.

questions.question_text: Arrange the Group 14 elements in increasing order of stability of +2 oxidation state: (A) C, (B) Si, (C) Ge, (D) Pb
questions.explanation_correct: The stability of the +2 oxidation state increases down the group due to the increasing importance of the inert pair effect. Carbon has the least stable +2 state, while lead has the most stable +2 state, making the order C, Si, Ge, Pb.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order is C, Si, Ge, Pb. This is because the inert pair effect, where the outermost s-electrons become less reactive, becomes more prominent as you go down the group. The +2 state is least stable for carbon and most stable for lead, so the order reflects the increasing stability of the +2 state from top to bottom in the group.

questions.question_text: How does the metallic character of boron differ from that of aluminium in terms of electrical conductivity?

options.text: Both are excellent conductors of electricity
Boron is a poor conductor while aluminium is a good conductor due to boron's metalloid nature
Aluminium is a poor conductor while boron is a good conductor

questions.explanation_correct: Boron is a metalloid and therefore a poor conductor of electricity, while aluminium is a true metal and exhibits good electrical conductivity. This difference arises from boron's small size, high ionization energy, and covalent bonding character, whereas aluminium has metallic bonding with delocalized electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B. Boron, being a metalloid, does not conduct electricity well due to its covalent nature and lack of free electrons. Aluminium, on the other hand, is a metal with metallic bonding and free electrons that allow it to conduct electricity efficiently. Options A, C, and D incorrectly describe the conductivity properties of these elements.

questions.question_text: A substance has the following properties: sp³ hybridization, tetrahedral structure, extremely hard, non-conductor of electricity. Identify the substance:
questions.explanation_correct: Diamond is the only carbon allotrope with sp³ hybridization, tetrahedral structure, extreme hardness, and non-conducting properties. All four valence electrons are locked in strong covalent bonds, leaving no free electrons for conduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Graphite has sp² hybridization and conducts electricity, so option A is incorrect. Fullerene (C) has a spherical structure, not tetrahedral. Silicon dioxide (D) contains silicon and oxygen, not pure carbon. The combination of sp³ hybridization, tetrahedral structure, hardness, and non-conductivity uniquely identifies diamond.

questions.question_text: Priya is working in a chemistry lab and needs to prepare a basic buffer solution using a boron compound. She dissolves borax in water. What pH range would she expect for this solution?
questions.explanation_correct: When borax (Na₂B₄O₇·10H₂O) dissolves in water, it undergoes hydrolysis to produce boric acid and sodium hydroxide. Since it is a salt of a weak acid (boric acid) and a strong base (NaOH), the solution will be basic with pH > 7. Priya would observe a pH typically around 9-10.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Borax does not produce an acidic solution (option A) because it is not a salt of a strong acid. It is also not neutral (option B) because the hydrolysis produces more hydroxide ions than hydrogen ions. The pH does not vary randomly (option D) but consistently remains above 7 due to the chemical nature of borax as a weak acid-strong base salt.

questions.question_text: All of the following Group 13 halides are covalent EXCEPT:
questions.explanation_correct: AlF₃ is ionic due to the high electronegativity difference between aluminium and fluorine, and the small size of F⁻ ion which allows effective ionic bonding with Al³⁺. All boron halides (BF₃, BCl₃, BBr₃) are covalent because boron's small size and high ionization energy prevent it from forming ionic bonds easily.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, C, and D are all boron halides which are covalent in nature due to boron's metalloid character and inability to easily lose electrons. AlF₃ is the exception because aluminium, being a metal, can form ionic compounds with highly electronegative fluorine. The small F⁻ ion and Al³⁺ cation have a strong electrostatic attraction that results in ionic bonding.

questions.question_text: Why does carbon form stable compounds with oxygen in the form of discrete molecules (CO₂) rather than extended networks?

options.text: Because carbon can form strong pπ-pπ multiple bonds with oxygen due to effective orbital overlap
Because carbon is larger than silicon

questions.explanation_correct: Carbon's small atomic size allows effective overlap of its p-orbitals with oxygen's p-orbitals, forming strong pπ-pπ double bonds in CO₂. This satisfies carbon's valency through multiple bonding in discrete molecules rather than requiring extended network structures. Silicon, being larger, cannot form such effective pπ-pπ bonds and thus forms network solids like SiO₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because carbon actually has relatively high electronegativity. Option C is wrong as carbon is smaller, not larger, than silicon. Option D, while true that carbon lacks d-orbitals, is not the primary reason for discrete molecule formation. The key factor (option B) is carbon's ability to form strong multiple bonds through effective p-orbital overlap, which silicon cannot achieve due to its larger size.

questions.question_text: A compound has Si-O-Si linkages, contains organic groups attached to silicon, and is water-repellent and thermally stable. Identify this class of compounds:
questions.explanation_correct: Silicones are organosilicon polymers with Si-O-Si backbone and organic groups (typically methyl groups) attached to silicon atoms. They are characterized by being chemically inert, water-repellent, and thermally stable, making them useful as lubricants and sealants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silicates (option A) are inorganic compounds based on SiO₄⁴⁻ tetrahedra and do not contain organic groups. Zeolites (option C) are hydrated aluminosilicates with microporous structures, not organic polymers. Borates (option D) contain boron, not silicon. The combination of Si-O-Si linkages with organic groups uniquely identifies silicones.

questions.question_text: Rohan conducts an experiment where he burns carbon in limited oxygen supply. He notices the formation of a colourless, odourless gas that is highly toxic. Later, he learns that this gas binds to hemoglobin 200-300 times more strongly than oxygen. Which gas did Rohan produce?
questions.explanation_correct: Rohan produced carbon monoxide (CO), which forms during incomplete combustion of carbon in limited oxygen supply. CO is colourless, odourless, and highly toxic because it binds to hemoglobin with much greater affinity than oxygen (200-300 times stronger), forming carboxyhemoglobin and blocking oxygen transport in the blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CO₂ (option A) is produced in complete combustion and is not highly toxic at normal concentrations. CH₄ (option C) is methane, which is not formed by burning carbon alone. C₂H₄ (option D) is ethylene, an organic compound not produced by simple carbon combustion. The key indicators—limited oxygen, colourless/odourless gas, extreme toxicity due to hemoglobin binding—all point to carbon monoxide (CO).

questions.question_text: How does the stability of the +1 oxidation state in thallium (Tl) differ from that in aluminium (Al) in terms of the inert pair effect?

options.text: Both show equal stability of +1 state
Tl shows stable +1 state due to strong inert pair effect; Al does not show stable +1 state
Al shows stable +1 state due to inert pair effect; Tl does not

questions.explanation_correct: Thallium (Tl), being a heavier Group 13 element, exhibits a strong inert pair effect where the 6s² electrons remain paired and unreactive, making the +1 oxidation state more stable than +3. Aluminium, being lighter and having no significant inert pair effect, strongly prefers the +3 oxidation state and rarely shows +1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the stability of +1 state differs significantly between Al and Tl. Option C reverses the correct relationship. Option D is wrong because Tl definitely shows +1 state (TlCl, Tl₂O). The inert pair effect increases down the group, so it is much more pronounced in heavier elements like Tl compared to lighter elements like Al.

questions.question_text: Amit is synthesizing a Lewis acid for his project on coordination chemistry. He chooses BF₃ because it can accept electron pairs. What property of boron makes BF₃ a Lewis acid?

options.text: Boron has excess electrons to donate
Boron has an incomplete octet and vacant p-orbital

questions.explanation_correct: BF₃ is a Lewis acid because boron has only 6 electrons in its valence shell (incomplete octet) with one vacant p-orbital. This vacant orbital can accept a lone pair of electrons from a Lewis base, forming a coordinate covalent bond. Boron's electron deficiency is the key property that makes its compounds Lewis acidic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because boron is electron-deficient, not electron-rich. Option C is wrong as BF₃ is covalent, not ionic. Option D is not the primary reason; while boron has moderate electronegativity, it's the incomplete octet and vacant orbital (option B) that makes BF₃ a Lewis acid by enabling it to accept electron pairs.

questions.question_text: All of the following statements about Group 14 elements are correct EXCEPT:

options.text: Carbon shows maximum catenation in the group
Lead preferentially shows +4 oxidation state over +2
Silicon forms SiO₄⁴⁻ tetrahedra in silicates
CCl₄ is not hydrolyzed by water

questions.explanation_correct: Statement B is incorrect because lead preferentially shows the +2 oxidation state over +4 due to the strong inert pair effect. The 6s² electrons in lead are stable and reluctant to participate in bonding, making Pb²⁺ compounds more stable than Pb⁴⁺ compounds. All other statements (A, C, D) are correct.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statement A is correct as carbon has the strongest C-C bonds enabling maximum catenation. Statement C is correct as silicon forms tetrahedral SiO₄⁴⁻ units in silicates. Statement D is correct because carbon lacks vacant d-orbitals to facilitate hydrolysis. Only statement B is the exception, as it incorrectly suggests lead prefers +4 when it actually prefers +2 due to the inert pair effect.

questions.question_text: Why does aluminium oxide (Al₂O₃) react with both acids and bases?

options.text: Because Al₂O₃ is amphoteric and can act as both acid and base
Because aluminium has a large atomic radius

questions.explanation_correct: Al₂O₃ is amphoteric, meaning it can react with both acids (acting as a base) and bases (acting as an acid). With acids, it forms Al³⁺ salts; with bases like NaOH, it forms aluminates (NaAlO₂). This amphoteric nature arises from aluminium's intermediate electronegativity and the polar covalent character of Al-O bonds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect as aluminium has moderate electronegativity, not high. Option C is irrelevant to amphoteric behavior. Option D is wrong because Al₂O₃ has significant covalent character, not purely ionic bonding. The correct reason (option B) is that amphoteric oxides can donate or accept protons depending on whether they react with acids or bases.

questions.question_text: A hydrated aluminosilicate has a microporous framework structure with channels that can selectively trap molecules based on size. It is used as a molecular sieve. Identify this material:
questions.explanation_correct: Zeolites are hydrated aluminosilicates with three-dimensional framework structures containing channels and cavities. These microporous structures allow them to act as molecular sieves, selectively adsorbing molecules based on size and shape. They are widely used as catalysts in the petrochemical industry and as ion exchangers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silicones (option A) are organosilicon polymers, not aluminosilicates. Borax (option B) is a sodium borate, not an aluminosilicate. Diborane (option D) is a boron hydride gas. The combination of aluminosilicate composition, microporous framework, and molecular sieving capability uniquely identifies zeolites.

questions.question_text: Meera is studying different forms of carbon for her physics project on conductors and insulators. She tests graphite and diamond for electrical conductivity. Which observation would she make?

options.text: Both graphite and diamond conduct electricity equally well
Graphite conducts electricity but diamond does not
Diamond conducts electricity but graphite does not
Neither graphite nor diamond conducts electricity

questions.explanation_correct: Meera would observe that graphite conducts electricity while diamond does not. Graphite has sp² hybridized carbon atoms with delocalized π-electrons that can move freely between layers, enabling electrical conduction. Diamond has sp³ hybridized carbon with all four valence electrons locked in strong covalent bonds, leaving no free electrons for conduction, making it an excellent insulator.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because diamond is an insulator, not a conductor. Option C reverses the correct relationship. Option D is wrong because graphite definitely conducts electricity due to its delocalized electrons. The structural difference—sp² hybridization with free electrons in graphite versus sp³ hybridization with no free electrons in diamond—explains why only graphite conducts electricity.

questions.question_text: How does the acidic character of boric acid (H₃BO₃) differ from that of phosphoric acid (H₃PO₄) in terms of proton donation?

options.text: Both are triprotic acids that donate three protons
Boric acid is a monobasic Lewis acid accepting OH⁻; phosphoric acid is a triprotic Brønsted acid donating H⁺
Both are Lewis acids accepting electron pairs

questions.explanation_correct: Boric acid acts as a monobasic Lewis acid by accepting OH⁻ ions from water (H₃BO₃ + H₂O → B(OH)₄⁻ + H⁺), not by directly donating protons. Phosphoric acid is a triprotic Brønsted acid that can donate up to three protons sequentially. This fundamental difference in acid mechanism distinguishes boric acid from typical oxyacids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because H₃BO₃ does not donate three protons like H₃PO₄. Option C is wrong as H₃PO₄ is primarily a Brønsted acid, not a Lewis acid. Option D is incorrect because both are weak acids, but they differ in their acidic mechanisms. The key difference (option B) is that boric acid accepts OH⁻ (Lewis acid behavior) while phosphoric acid donates H⁺ (Brønsted acid behavior).

questions.question_text: Arjun is performing a thermite welding demonstration where aluminium powder reacts with iron(III) oxide. The reaction produces intense heat and molten iron. What role does aluminium play in this reaction?
questions.explanation_correct: In the thermite reaction (2Al + Fe₂O₃ → Al₂O₃ + 2Fe), aluminium acts as a strong reducing agent. It donates electrons to Fe³⁺ ions, reducing them to metallic iron (Fe⁰), while aluminium itself is oxidized from Al⁰ to Al³⁺ in Al₂O₃. The reaction is highly exothermic, releasing enough heat to produce molten iron used in welding.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because aluminium is being oxidized (losing electrons), not reduced. Option C is wrong as aluminium is consumed in the reaction, not acting as a catalyst. Option D is incorrect because aluminium actively participates in the redox reaction. As a reducing agent (option B), aluminium's strong affinity for oxygen drives the reaction forward with significant heat release.

questions.question_text: All of the following compounds undergo hydrolysis readily EXCEPT:
questions.explanation_correct: CCl₄ does not undergo hydrolysis because carbon lacks vacant d-orbitals that would allow water molecules to attack. In contrast, SiCl₄, GeCl₄, and SnCl₄ all have vacant d-orbitals that can accept lone pairs from water, facilitating nucleophilic attack and hydrolysis. This is why CCl₄ is stable in water while SiCl₄ hydrolyzes violently.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, C, and D all undergo hydrolysis because silicon, germanium, and tin have vacant d-orbitals available for expansion of their coordination sphere. CCl₄ is the exception because carbon (second period element) has no accessible d-orbitals. Additionally, the high C-Cl bond strength and carbon's small size create steric protection against nucleophilic attack by water.

questions.question_text: Why does diborane (B₂H₆) have a unique three-centre two-electron bonding structure?

options.text: Because boron has excess electrons to share
Because boron is electron-deficient and cannot form normal 2c-2e bonds for all six B-H connections
Because boron has very high electronegativity

questions.explanation_correct: Boron is electron-deficient with only 3 valence electrons. In B₂H₆, there are only 12 valence electrons total (6 from two B atoms, 6 from six H atoms) but 8 bonds would be needed for conventional 2c-2e bonding. This electron deficiency is resolved through two 3-centre 2-electron (banana) bonds where one electron pair bonds one B atom to two H atoms simultaneously, allowing stable structure formation with fewer electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because boron is electron-deficient, not electron-rich. Option C is wrong as the bonding preference comes from boron's deficiency, not hydrogen's preference. Option D is incorrect as boron has moderate electronegativity. The key reason (option B) is that boron lacks sufficient electrons for conventional bonding, necessitating the unique 3c-2e banana bonds to form a stable molecule.

questions.question_text: A carbon structure has the following features: consists of 60 carbon atoms arranged in pentagons and hexagons forming a spherical cage resembling a soccer ball. Identify this allotrope:
questions.explanation_correct: This describes fullerene C₆₀, also known as buckminsterfullerene. It consists of 60 carbon atoms arranged in a truncated icosahedron shape with 12 pentagons and 20 hexagons, resembling a soccer ball. This was the first fullerene discovered and represents a unique class of carbon allotropes distinct from diamond and graphite.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diamond (option A) has a tetrahedral lattice structure, not a spherical cage. Graphite (option B) has planar hexagonal layers, not a closed cage. Carbon nanotubes (option D) are cylindrical, not spherical. The combination of 60 carbon atoms in a soccer-ball shape with pentagons and hexagons uniquely identifies fullerene C₆₀.

questions.question_text: Riya is studying the reaction of aluminium hydroxide with different reagents. She adds hydrochloric acid to one sample and sodium hydroxide solution to another. What would she observe in both cases?

options.text: Al(OH)₃ dissolves only in HCl, forming AlCl₃
Al(OH)₃ dissolves only in NaOH, forming sodium aluminate
Al(OH)₃ dissolves in both HCl and NaOH, forming AlCl₃ and sodium aluminate respectively
Al(OH)₃ does not dissolve in either reagent

questions.explanation_correct: Riya would observe that aluminium hydroxide dissolves in both reagents because it is amphoteric. With HCl (acid), it acts as a base: Al(OH)₃ + 3HCl → AlCl₃ + 3H₂O. With NaOH (base), it acts as an acid: Al(OH)₃ + NaOH → NaAlO₂ + 2H₂O. This amphoteric behavior is characteristic of aluminium compounds and demonstrates aluminium's intermediate position in the periodic table.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A and B are partially correct but incomplete, as they describe only one reaction. Option D is incorrect because Al(OH)₃ definitely dissolves in both acids and bases. The complete observation (option C) reflects the amphoteric nature of aluminium hydroxide, which can react as either a base (with acids) or an acid (with bases).

questions.question_text: Why is the Si-Si bond enthalpy (226 kJ/mol) significantly lower than the C-C bond enthalpy (348 kJ/mol)?

options.text: Because silicon is more electronegative than carbon
Because silicon has a larger atomic size, resulting in poorer orbital overlap and weaker bonds
Because silicon forms ionic bonds while carbon forms covalent bonds
Because silicon has fewer valence electrons than carbon

questions.explanation_correct: Silicon has a much larger atomic radius than carbon (117 pm vs. 77 pm). This larger size results in longer Si-Si bonds with poorer overlap of valence orbitals, producing weaker bonds with lower bond enthalpy. The stronger C-C bonds allow carbon to form long stable chains (catenation), while silicon's weaker Si-Si bonds make silicon chains less stable, explaining why silicon shows limited catenation compared to carbon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect as silicon is actually less electronegative than carbon. Option C is wrong because both silicon and carbon form covalent bonds, not ionic. Option D is incorrect as both have four valence electrons. The correct reason (option B) is the size difference: larger atoms form longer, weaker bonds due to reduced orbital overlap.
